properties.text: When gathering firewood, look for dry, hard wood with little or no bark.
Damp wood is harder to ignite and keep burning.

There are many types of edible mushrooms that can be found in North America. 

In this area, you might be able to find some Oyster Mushrooms like these. They are nutritious and safe to eat, and often grow on fallen trees or stumps.

Be careful when foraging for mushrooms- Some can be harmful or even fatal for humans to eat. 

One type that might be found in this area is known as Pholiotina Rugosa. It is tall, brown, skinny mushroom and is often found growing in dung or rich soil. Be sure to avoid this mushroom when foraging. Ingesting it can lead to severe illness or death.

Once the fire is going, you can purify the water you collected earlier by boiling it over the fire. Heating up the water can kill any bacteria that might have been living in it, making it much safer to drink. 


Place a metal jug directly on the fire to bring it to a boil. Make sure you find a flat, stable area of the fire to place you jug to avoid spilling your water. Also make sure you allow your vessel to cool before you drink your newly-purified water.
Pick up the vessel and carry it to the safest water source. Then, hold it over the fire to sanitize and drink it.
You can never know for sure if a water source is safe to drink, but running water is usually safer than stagnant water.
It is easier for harmful bacteria and other contaminates to grow in stagnant water.

To start the fire, brace a straight, dry stick on top of another flat, dry piece of wood. With an open palm on each side of the stick, rub your hands together causing the stick to grind against the wood. 

This video demonstrates the proper motion. This method is laborious, but with enough effort you can create an ember that you can then feed with kindling to create a roaring fire.

Building a fire can be hard if you don’t have flint, matches or a lighter. 

Once you’ve collected firewood and kindling, clear the site where you want to build the fire of any vegetation.
